pr_title: Create an object to track state between fire rounds

timeline.message: Create an object to track state between fire rounds

timeline.bodyText:
I'm noticing this is a mutable object.
Would you agree it's better to have mutable references to immutable objects than it is to have an final reference to a mutable object?
Can we instead have this be a @Value?
timeline.author: DanVanAtta

replies.bodyText:
I agree that it is better to have mutable references to immutable objects.  And that is basically what this is.  It is a collection of mutable references to two mostly immutable objects.  DiceRoll appears to be completely immutable and could probably be marked as @Value and CasualtyDetails looks like it could be made completely immutable and my changes only use it in an immutable manner.
And this can't be a @Value because the three steps need to access and update these references.  The first one will update the dice roll.  The second will use the dice roll to update the casualty details.  And the third uses both the dice roll and the casualty details.
replies.author: trevan

replies.bodyText: Instead of accessing and updating this object, what if a new one were created and that new value then passed forward? Is this a good use-case for the lombok toBuilder() where you can create a mutated copy of an object?
replies.author: DanVanAtta

replies.bodyText: I'd love to do that.  But IExecutables in the stack don't share anything.  You can't pass things between them.
replies.author: trevan
